    Embedding img into Markdown file

    vuePress-theme-reco Cody Chen    2023

    Embedding img into Markdown file

    Cody Chen 5/29/2023 PythonMarkdown
    • Problem and Solution
    • Functionality
    • Creating Script
      • Use a file selection dialog to choose a file or read an image from the clipboard
      • Convert the image to Base64 encoding
      • Pass the resulting Base64 encoding to the clipboard
      • Complete python code
    • Steps to follow
    • Addition

    # Problem and Solution

    When using Markdown to document notes and share them across different devices, images embedded in the Markdown file cannot be displayed directly. Markdown relies on referencing image paths rather than embedding them. To achieve image embedding similar to Word documents, the solution involves converting image paths to Base64 encoding, allowing for image insertion within the Markdown file.

    # Functionality

    • After taking a screenshot, paste it into a Markdown document and save the path as a base64 format.
    • When not using screenshots, you can select a local image and automatically save it as a base64 format in a Markdown document.

    # Creating Script

    # Use a file selection dialog to choose a file or read an image from the clipboard

    • Select a file from the file dialog.
    import win32ui
 dlg = win32ui.CreateFileDialog(1)  # 1 represents open file dialog
 dlg.SetOFNInitialDir('C:\\Users\\Desktop')  # setting the initial directory when opening dialog
 dlg.DoModal()
 filename = dlg.GetPathName()  # acquiring the file path and name
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5
    • Getting img from clip board
    from PIL import ImageGrab
im = ImageGrab.grabclipboard()# retrieve the file from the clipboard.
if isinstance(im, Image.Image):
 img = im
else:
 pass
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5
    6

    # Convert the image to Base64 encoding

    with open("C:\\Users\\Desktop\\1.jpg", 'rb') as f:
 base64_data = base64.b64encode(f.read())
 s = base64_data.decode()
 print('(data:image/jpeg;base64,%s) \n'%s)</pre>
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5

    # Pass the resulting Base64 encoding to the clipboard

    @echo off
python C:\\Users\\Desktop\\base64pic.py | clip
    1
    2
    • Save the cmd code as bat file

    # Complete python code

    import win32ui, os, base64
from PIL import Image, ImageGrab

im = ImageGrab.grabclipboard()
if isinstance(im, Image.Image):
    img = im
else:
    dlg = win32ui.CreateFileDialog(1)  # 1 represents the open file dialog
    dlg.SetOFNInitialDir(r'C:\Users\desktop')  # Set the initial directory for the open file dialog
    dlg.DoModal()
    filename = dlg.GetPathName()  # Get the selected file name
    img = Image.open(filename)

img.thumbnail((778, 439), Image.LANCZOS)
img = img.convert('RGB')
img.save("C:\\Users\\desktop\\1.jpg", quality=70)

with open("C:\\Users\\desktop\\1.jpg", 'rb') as f:
    base64_data = base64.b64encode(f.read())
    s = base64_data.decode()
    print('![](data:image/jpeg;base64,%s)' % s)

os.remove("C:\\Users\\desktop\\1.jpg")

    # Steps to follow

    • After capturing a screenshot, launch the bat file. The copied text will be the Base64-encoded image.
    • Alternatively, directly run the bat file and choose the relevant image using the file selection dialog.

    # Addition

    • package download
      • $ pip install pillow for PIL
      • $ pip install pypiwin32 for win32ui
    • As the Base64 encoding can have a long length, you can consider the following format for saving:
    ![image][tmp]
your document here ...

[tmp]:data:image/png;base64, ......
